Making India a Manufacturing Hub - Is it a dream or a practical possibility? Discuss three key factors for making `Make in India` a reality.

Make  in india is a type of swadeshi movement covering 25 sectors of economy was launched by the government of india on 25th september 2014 to encourage companies to manufacture their products in india and also increase their investment . As per the current policy 100% FDI permitted in all the 25 sectors , expect for space , defence and news media . japan and india had also announced aus b$ 12 billion japan - india make in india special finance facility fund to push investment.

After launching" make in india " india has got so many worthy investment commitments. India emerged as the top destination globally in 2015.strong initiatives such as the GST are the reason for the new india . our prime minister has proposed this make in india and also he had came up with many new ideas to develop india such as swach bharat, digital India, beti bachavo beti padavo soo many changes.

Narendra modi ji has started this make in india on 25th september 2014 as on 3years has passed it was continuing with success and with soo many reward and investment commitments. and this make in india is completely a practical one not any dream to imagine that india would be like this if we start this or anything. It is a completely a practical ly possible thing and it is running with its success . as  on 3 years has passed it has achieved its succes it practically and not dramatically . if one can start his step everyone wil go on follow their footsteps if no one starts after  20 years also it will be still developing nation.

the 3 key factors of making india reality is its vision,support,hardworking investments new ideas.

1.vision :as starting the program of making india they had kept one vision to achieve .

2. support :as people supporting his thoughts he is going on achieveing his program.

3. hardworking: if the workers or employers of the program are hardworkers , sincerety then the program will get succes and the investments go on increase and their will be a developed nation without doubt and its not any dream but it is a  practically possible thing.

with that success we have started so many  things  like digital india , GST, so that people can also develop their minds .and also many schemes with this making india he had started . by this india has toped as globally developed nation by 2015. The government has started so many things but the well good things to develop the country was making india, digital india , and the last GST . these things will be good enough to india if they was worked practically. the government enacted legally with gst implementation and worked very crucially on those days . with this gst india really played avery prominent role .

Brazilian Smart Grid Market -An Insight

brazil is the fifth largest population in the world which is already one of the leading emerging market countries in terms of smart grid development.And agovernment that is eager to modernize the country`s infrastructure.By the end of the decade it will be one of the largest smart grid markets.It is the product of strong underlying market conditions and positive government actions. It was the rapidly growing economy with high rates of non- technical distribution  losses. which will reap immediate revenue protection benefits which is the beginning to strain existing infrstructure.The smart grid will become increasingly important if the energy saving benefits and the reliability of the country continues to grow.The government has taken notice but in 2009 it has set a non binding target of replacing all 63 million existing electromechanical meters with smart meters by 2021.

But in august 2012  the brazil government has came up with an new meter that is "opt-in"  its a regulation for existing customers with paired of mandate requiring for all new customers. It is not any anticipated market catalyst for those  who are expecting a binding mandate to replace all 63 million existing legacy meters with smart meters.But now the northeast group is calculating and imaginating that brazil will not reach its 63 million smart meter target but the government officials and regulators are still encouraging brazil with optimistic that the initial goal of smart meters will be reached.that may inspire their future incentive structure and smart metering regualtions.

But inevitably that brazil`s smart grid market will rapidly grow in the coming decades by the underlying economic and political conditions,this will enable us to know how fast deployments will take place.by the combination of new meter installations smart meter targetted reduced by the non technical losses and the customer eager to take advantage of advanced smart grid applications.By this most of the brazilian homes will also have the smart meters by the decade. but brazil has to meet its original goal of 63 million meters by 2021 however the august 2012  regualtion had felt short of the concrete mandate .but at last brazil remains a very significant smart grid market for both vendors and customers alike brazil is one of the largest growing country in smart meters.

Global Smart Grid Vendor Landscape

The smart grid vendor landscape is undergoing a period of change. In developed countries in North America, Europe, and East Asia, markets are maturing and vendors are consolidating. Several of the larger vendors now offer integrated solutions throughout the smart metering value chain, while communications and data analytics providers are increasingly active across multiple smart grid segments, improving the coordination between smart metering, distribution automation and home energy management. Meanwhile, in emerging market countries – across Africa, Central & Eastern Europe, Eurasia, Latin America, the Middle East & North Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia – the market is just beginning to grow. Dozens of local vendors have begun to serve smart grid projects, both on their own and as partners of larger international firms. With high growth rates projected for smart grid projects in emerging market countries, this represents the next frontier of vendor activity and opportunity. The dynamics between growing and consolidating international smart grid vendors and smaller, more fragmented local players will help shape the speed and direction of smart grid deployments across the globe. This study takes a comprehensive look at the trends shaping the smart grid vendor landscape and how firms are positioning themselves to succeed. It includes over 500 vendors already active in smart grid projects across all regions of the world, highlights growing regions and market segments, and assesses the existing partnerships, mergers, and acquisitions that are altering the smart grid market. Across 125 countries, smart grid investment will reach $380.1 billion between 2015 and 2025. This study presents a picture of the competitive landscape of the hundreds of vendors competing for this growing market.

 

Brazilian Smart Grid Market – An Insight

Brazil is already one of the leading emerging market countries in terms of smart grid development. With the fifth largest population in the world and a government that is eager to modernize the country’s infrastructure, Brazil will become one of the largest smart grid markets in the world by the end of the decade. Brazil’s smart grid development is the product of strong underlying market conditions and positive government action. Like many emerging market countries, Brazil has high rates of non--‐technical distribution losses, implying  that utilities  will  reap immediate revenue protection benefits through smart meter deployments. Brazil also has a rapidly growing economy, which is beginning to strain existing infrastructure. As  the country continues to grow, the reliability and  energy savings benefits of smart grid will become increasingly important. The Brazilian government has  taken notice and in 2009 it  set a non--‐binding target of replacing  all  63  million  existing  electromechanical  meters  with  smart  meters  by  2021. 

However,  in  August    2012, the  government  announced  an  “opt--‐in”  smart  meter   regulation  for  existing  customers,   Paired with  a  mandate  requiring  smart  meters  for  all  new  customers.  This  was  not  the  anticipated  market  catalyst  for    those  expecting  a  binding  mandate  to  replace  all  63  million existing legacy  meters  with  smart  meters.  As  a  result,  Northeast  Group   is  currently forecasting that Brazil will not reach its initial 63 million smart meter target. Yet, some government officials and regulators are still optimistic that the initial goal can be achieved, which may inspire future incentive structures and more favorable smart metering regulations.

With strong underlying economic and political conditions, it is inevitable that Brazil’s smart grid market will grow significantly in the coming decade. The question is simply how fast deployments will take place. Through a combination of new meter installations, smart meters targeted at reducing non--‐ technical losses, and customers eager to take advantage of advanced smart grid applications, more than half of Brazilian homes will have smart meters by the end of the decade. However, the August 2012 regulations fell short of the concrete mandate needed for Brazil to meet it’s original goal of 63 million meters by 2021. Nonetheless, Brazil remains a very significant smart grid market for both vendors and customers alike.
